Title:
Whole genome sequence analysis indicates recent
diversification of mammal-associated Campylobacter fetus and implicates
a genetic factor associated with H2S production.
Abstract:
Background: Campylobacter fetus (C. fetus) can cause
disease in both humans and animals. C. fetus has been divided into three
subspecies: C. fetus subsp. fetus (Cff), C. fetus subsp. venerealis
(Cfv) and C. fetus subsp. testudinum (Cft). Subspecies identification of
mammal-associated C. fetus strains is crucial in the control of Bovine
Genital Campylobacteriosis (BGC), a syndrome associated with Cfv. The
prescribed methods for subspecies identification of the Cff and Cfv
isolates are: tolerance to 1% glycine and H2S production. Results: In
this study, we observed the deletion of a putative cysteine transporter
in the Cfv strains, which are not able to produce H2S from L-cysteine.
Phylogenetic reconstruction of the core genome single nucleotide
polymorphisms (SNPs) within Cff and Cfv strains divided these strains
into five different clades and showed that the Cfv clade and a Cff clade
evolved from a single Cff ancestor. Conclusions: Multiple C. fetus
clades were observed, which were not consistent with the biochemical
differentiation of the strains. This suggests the need for a closer
evaluation of the current C. fetus subspecies differentiation,
considering that the phenotypic differentiation is still applied in BGC
control programs.
